  <strong style="display: block;">
  An analyst estimates a company’s equity beta using daily returns and finds β=0.3. However, using monthly data, β=1.1. Which econometric issue best explains this discrepancy?
  </strong>

  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q97" value="A"> A. Non-synchronous trading and measurement error at high frequencies (the “errors-in-variables” problem).</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q97" value="B"> B. The firm’s true beta changes every month with macroeconomic cycles.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q97" value="C"> C. Daily betas are always biased downward, while monthly betas are always unbiased.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q97" value="D"> D. CAPM is valid only with monthly data.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q97" value="E"> E. Liquidity-adjusted betas eliminate this discrepancy.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module4_mcq_q97" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: A. High-frequency data often suffer from non-synchronous trading and measurement errors, biasing β estimates downward. Monthly data reduce this issue.
